qas.question: Which professor cited by Popper described the creation-evolution debate as "a storm in a Victorian tea-cup?"
What controversy involving science did Popper believe was sensationalized because of its connection with religion?
In which year did C.E. Raven publish the remarks on creation-evolution quoted by Popper?
What term does Popper use when describing creationism as a type of theory?
Who wrote that the creation-evolution controversy was "not sensational" ?
Who did Professor Raven say he agreed with?
In what book did Popper called the conflict "a storm in a Victorian tea-cup"?
In what year did Popper publish Science, Religion, and the Future?
Who thought the force of Popper's remarks was impaired to the attention he paid to the conflict?

context: About the <a1_0>creation-evolution<a1_0/> controversy, <b4_0><b5_0>Popper<b5_0/><b4_0/> wrote that he considered it "a somewhat sensational clash between a brilliant scientific hypothesis concerning the history of the various species of animals and plants on earth, and an older <a3_0>metaphysical<a3_0/> theory which, incidentally, happened to be part of an established religious belief" with a footnote to the effect that "[he] agree[s] with <b8_0>Professor <a0_0>C.E. Raven<b8_0/><a0_0/> when, in his <b6_0>Science, Religion, and the Future<b6_0/>, <a2_0><b7_0>1943<b7_0/><a2_0/>, he calls this conflict "a storm in a Victorian tea-cup"; though the force of this remark is perhaps a little impaired by the attention he pays to the vapours still emerging from the cup—to the Great Systems of Evolutionist Philosophy, produced by Bergson, Whitehead, Smuts, and others."
